<<probability_distribution_summary>>

Probability of exactly $$k$$ successes out of $$n$$ trials.

$$
\displaystyle
B(n, p) =
\underbrace{
\underbrace{\quad p^k\quad}
_{\begin{gathered}
				\text{prob. of}\\
				k\\
				\text{successes}
  \end{gathered}}
\times
\underbrace{(1-p)^{n-k}}
_{\begin{gathered}
				\text{prob. of}\\
				n - k\\
				\text{failures}
  \end{gathered}}
}_{\text{all }n\text{ trials covered}}
\times
\underbrace{n \choose k}
_{\begin{gathered}
				\text{num. of}\\
				\text{such}\\
				\text{combi-}\\
				\text{nations}
  \end{gathered}}
$$

It is called [[Binomial|Binomial Distribution]] because the proof that it sums up to $$1$$ involves the [[Binomial Theorem]].

* If $$X_1 \sim B(n,p_1)$$ and $$X_2 \sim B(n,p_2)$$, then $$X_1 + X_2 \sim B(n, p_1 + p_2)$$.
